channel.title: Nebulae
channel.description: The nebulae of the Milky Way.

item.title: California Nebula - smoothed
item.description: This is a slightly smoothed version of the California nebula. This process reduces noise in the nebulosity and also reduces the hot pixel artifacts. Atik CCD with RGB filters on the 80 mm apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description: This is a slightly smoothed version of the California nebula. This process reduces noise in the nebulosity and also reduces the hot pixel artifacts. Atik CCD with RGB filters on the 80 mm apochromatic refractor.

item.title: California nebula - rotated
item.description: This version of the California nebula is rotated so that it better resembles the state of california when North is up. Atik CCD on 80 mm apo.
item.media:description: This version of the California nebula is rotated so that it better resembles the state of california when North is up. Atik CCD on 80 mm apo.

item.title: California Nebula
item.description: The California Nebula in Perseus taken with the Atik CCD with RGB filters on the 80 mm Apo. This nebula is about 5 full moons long, but it is too faint to see with the naked eye.
item.media:description: The California Nebula in Perseus taken with the Atik CCD with RGB filters on the 80 mm Apo. This nebula is about 5 full moons long, but it is too faint to see with the naked eye.

item.title: Cone Nebula
item.description:
The Cone Nebula, also known as NGC 2264. The red line visible through the picture is due to a satellite passing through the field of view during the red filter exposure.
Atik 343L CCD, 80mm Meade apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description:
The Cone Nebula, also known as NGC 2264. The red line visible through the picture is due to a satellite passing through the field of view during the red filter exposure.
Atik 343L CCD, 80mm Meade apochromatic refractor.

item.title: Cone Nebula
item.description: The Cone nebula (LDN 1613) is a dark, cone-like feature to the right of center. The center has a brighter, reddish emission nebula called NGC 2264 or the fox fur nebula. The whole complex of star clusters and nebula is called the Christmas Tree nebula. Atik CCD in RGB filters on the 80 mm apo refractor. The red line is a satellite trail.
item.media:description: The Cone nebula (LDN 1613) is a dark, cone-like feature to the right of center. The center has a brighter, reddish emission nebula called NGC 2264 or the fox fur nebula. The whole complex of star clusters and nebula is called the Christmas Tree nebula. Atik CCD in RGB filters on the 80 mm apo refractor. The red line is a satellite trail.

item.title: M27
item.description:
M27, the Dumbbell Nebula in Vulpecula.
One of the better pictures taken with the Meade DSI II CCD. Used the Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor. Color is fairly accurate and hot pixels were removed. N is up.
item.media:description:
M27, the Dumbbell Nebula in Vulpecula.
One of the better pictures taken with the Meade DSI II CCD. Used the Meade 80mm apochromatic refractor. Color is fairly accurate and hot pixels were removed. N is up.

item.title: M27 - Dumbbell Nebula
item.description: M27, the Dumbbell Nebula in Vulpecula. Atik 383L CCD on the Celestron 11-inch using RGB filters.
item.media:description: M27, the Dumbbell Nebula in Vulpecula. Atik 383L CCD on the Celestron 11-inch using RGB filters.

item.title: M27 - G filter.
item.description: Messier 27, the Dumbell Nebula in Vulpecula. This is one of the brightest examples of planetary nebulas in the sky. This is an image taken through the G (green) filter of the Atik CCD camera on the Celestron C11.
item.media:description: Messier 27, the Dumbell Nebula in Vulpecula. This is one of the brightest examples of planetary nebulas in the sky. This is an image taken through the G (green) filter of the Atik CCD camera on the Celestron C11.

item.title: Messier 27 - red filter.
item.description: Messier 27, the Dumbell Nebula in Vulpecula. This is an image taken through the R (green) filter of the Atik CCD camera on the Celestron C11. Quickly blink between the G and R image to see that different regions of the nebula brighten. This is because some regions have stronger [OIII] emission lines (which are green) and some regions have stronger H-alpha emission (which is red).
item.media:description: Messier 27, the Dumbell Nebula in Vulpecula. This is an image taken through the R (green) filter of the Atik CCD camera on the Celestron C11. Quickly blink between the G and R image to see that different regions of the nebula brighten. This is because some regions have stronger [OIII] emission lines (which are green) and some regions have stronger H-alpha emission (which is red).

item.title: Eskimo Nebula
item.description: The Eskimo Nebula - a planetary nebula in Gemini. This faint, outer shell is reminiscent of the hood of a winter parka. Taken in 2011 using the DSI II CCD on the Meade 12" LX200.
item.media:description: The Eskimo Nebula - a planetary nebula in Gemini. This faint, outer shell is reminiscent of the hood of a winter parka. Taken in 2011 using the DSI II CCD on the Meade 12" LX200.

item.title: Eskimo Nebula
item.description: The Eskimo Nebula, a planetary nebula in the constellation of Gemini, aka Caldwell 39 or NGC 2392. Taken with the Canon T5i on 2019-03-25.
item.media:description: The Eskimo Nebula, a planetary nebula in the constellation of Gemini, aka Caldwell 39 or NGC 2392. Taken with the Canon T5i on 2019-03-25.

item.title: Flame and Horsehead Nebulae
item.description:
The Flame Nebula and Horsehead Nebula are two nebulae in the Orion Molecular Complex. The Flame Nebula is in the lower center, and the Horsehead Nebula is to the center right. The bright blue star in the image is Alnitak, the leftmost star on Orion's belt.
Taken with an Atik 343L CCD and an 80mm Meade apochromatic refractor. A reversed color palatte is used with green assigned to red, otherwise the horsehead would look red.
item.media:description:
The Flame Nebula and Horsehead Nebula are two nebulae in the Orion Molecular Complex. The Flame Nebula is in the lower center, and the Horsehead Nebula is to the center right. The bright blue star in the image is Alnitak, the leftmost star on Orion's belt.
Taken with an Atik 343L CCD and an 80mm Meade apochromatic refractor. A reversed color palatte is used with green assigned to red, otherwise the horsehead would look red.

item.title: Horsehead and Flame nebulae.
item.description: The Horsehead Nebula is oriented so that the horse looks upright in this rotated image. The Flame nebula is below the bright star Alnitak.
item.media:description: The Horsehead Nebula is oriented so that the horse looks upright in this rotated image. The Flame nebula is below the bright star Alnitak.

item.title: The Horsehead nebula and Alnitak
item.description: The bright star Alnitak (below center) is one of the three stars in the belt of Orion. Just to its right is the Flame Nebula, and above it is the Horsehead Nebula. The Horsehead is created by a dust cloud blocking the light from the background, red nebulosity.
item.media:description: The bright star Alnitak (below center) is one of the three stars in the belt of Orion. Just to its right is the Flame Nebula, and above it is the Horsehead Nebula. The Horsehead is created by a dust cloud blocking the light from the background, red nebulosity.

item.title: Flame and Horsehead Nebulae
item.description: The Flame Nebula (left) and Horsehead Nebula (center, barely visible) in Orion. The bright star is Alnitak. This is only an 90 second exposure, ISO 800, using the Canon T5i on the 80 mm refractor.
item.media:description: The Flame Nebula (left) and Horsehead Nebula (center, barely visible) in Orion. The bright star is Alnitak. This is only an 90 second exposure, ISO 800, using the Canon T5i on the 80 mm refractor.

item.title: Flaming Star Nebula
item.description: The Flaming Star Nebula (IC 405), in the constellation Auriga. North is up and east is to the left. Taken with Atik 383L on Meade 80mm Apochromatic Reflector.
item.media:description: The Flaming Star Nebula (IC 405), in the constellation Auriga. North is up and east is to the left. Taken with Atik 383L on Meade 80mm Apochromatic Reflector.

item.title: Messier 8 and surroundings.
item.description: Messier 8 (or the Lagoon nebula) in Sagittarius. This is an emission nebula near a star cluster. This is only a 30 second exposure with the Canon T5i on the Meade apochromatic refractor. This is too short of an exposure to bring out the glory of this nebula.
item.media:description: Messier 8 (or the Lagoon nebula) in Sagittarius. This is an emission nebula near a star cluster. This is only a 30 second exposure with the Canon T5i on the Meade apochromatic refractor. This is too short of an exposure to bring out the glory of this nebula.

item.title: Lagoon and Trifid Nebulas
item.description: The Lagoon Nebula (M8, right) and the Trifid Nebula (M20, left) in Sagittarius. The colors are not quite accurate. Atik 383L CCD through RGB filters on the 80 mm apochromatic refractor. N is up and E is left.
item.media:description: The Lagoon Nebula (M8, right) and the Trifid Nebula (M20, left) in Sagittarius. The colors are not quite accurate. Atik 383L CCD through RGB filters on the 80 mm apochromatic refractor. N is up and E is left.

item.title: M76
item.description: M76, the Little Dumbbell nebula. Named after M27, the Dumbbell Nebula, which has a similar appearance. Both are planetary nebulas, the remnants of stars that have finished fusing helium into carbon but were not massive enough to go supernova. Atik CCD on Celestron C11.
item.media:description: M76, the Little Dumbbell nebula. Named after M27, the Dumbbell Nebula, which has a similar appearance. Both are planetary nebulas, the remnants of stars that have finished fusing helium into carbon but were not massive enough to go supernova. Atik CCD on Celestron C11.

item.title: Omega Nebula (M17).
item.description: The Omega Nebula (or Messier 17) in the constellation Sagittarius. This was a single, 30 second exposure, taken with the Canon T5i on the Meade apochromatic refractor. The reddish hue of the top left is a noise artifact.
item.media:description: The Omega Nebula (or Messier 17) in the constellation Sagittarius. This was a single, 30 second exposure, taken with the Canon T5i on the Meade apochromatic refractor. The reddish hue of the top left is a noise artifact.

item.title: M17 - Omega Nebula
item.description: The Omega Nebula (or "Swan Nebula"), Messier 17 in Sagittarius. Atik 383 L CCD on the Celestron 11-inch.
item.media:description: The Omega Nebula (or "Swan Nebula"), Messier 17 in Sagittarius. Atik 383 L CCD on the Celestron 11-inch.

item.title: The Great Orion Nebula and surroundings.
item.description: M42, the Great Orion Nebula. A wide field view with North to the left instead of the usual orientation. The star clusters make up the sword of Orion. Canon T5i (90 sec) on the Meade 80 mm apochromatic refractor.
item.media:description: M42, the Great Orion Nebula. A wide field view with North to the left instead of the usual orientation. The star clusters make up the sword of Orion. Canon T5i (90 sec) on the Meade 80 mm apochromatic refractor.

item.title: Messier 42 in Orion's belt
item.description: Messier 42, or the Great Orion Nebula, in Orion's belt. This is a "deeper" exposure bringing out more of the faint nebulosity. The bluish reflection nebula above M42 is NGC 1975. North is up and East to left. Taken with the Atik 383L+ CCD through RGB filters on the Meade 80 mm refractor.
item.media:description: Messier 42, or the Great Orion Nebula, in Orion's belt. This is a "deeper" exposure bringing out more of the faint nebulosity. The bluish reflection nebula above M42 is NGC 1975. North is up and East to left. Taken with the Atik 383L+ CCD through RGB filters on the Meade 80 mm refractor.

item.title: Messier 42 in Orion's belt
item.description: Messier 42, or the Great Orion Nebula, in Orion's belt. North is up and E to left. Taken with the Atik 383L+ CCD through RGB filters on the Meade 80 mm refractor.
item.media:description: Messier 42, or the Great Orion Nebula, in Orion's belt. North is up and E to left. Taken with the Atik 383L+ CCD through RGB filters on the Meade 80 mm refractor.
